participants.participant: Didier Valet, Group Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to Société Générale Group First Quarter 2008 Results Conference Call. The presentation hosted by Mr. Frédéric Oudea, Chief Executive Officer, will be followed by a question-and-answer session. . Now, I would like to hand over to Mr. Oudea. Sir, please go ahead.

Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen and welcome to this conference call. In a few moments, I am going to hand over to our new CFO, Didier Valet, who will present to you the results for the first quarter of 2008 and answer your questions with our colleagues of the Executive Committee. Before that, however, I would like to say a few words in my new position as the CEO.

The financial market environment was very difficult in the first quarter, as you know, especially in the credit markets, and our financial statements are still feeling the effects of the financial crises, which were mitigated – moderated I would say in Corporate and Investment Banking by non-recurring and volatile accounting items but basically my reading of these accounts is very positive, and I am confident on the state of our businesses. We have a very solid base, with very strong performances in our retail banking activities, both in France and outside France. Our Private Banking franchise remains intact. Our services to investors have very strong performances, and we have basically finished expanding the impact of the financial crises on our dynamic monetary market funds in Asset Management. Eventually, regarding CIB, we record a satisfactory commercial performance across all our activities in a very difficult market climate.

The exceptional commitment and efforts of the group's personnel means that we have managed to bounce back very quickly and are now ready to continue our development, thanks to our solid financial structure. I would like, again, to take the opportunity to thank all our shareholders for massively supporting the capital increase and confirming their confidence in us. The reinforced general management team, which was announced today, and all my colleagues are totally committed to generating profitable growth and deliver the strategy that we've presented to the market so my mandate from that perspective is absolutely clear and simple – deliver the results that we have presented to you.
I just would like also to thank you all for your cooperation, your kind listening, during my five and a half years as the Group CFO, and I look forward seeing you again.
Didier, over to you for the detailed comments on the results.

Frédéric, thank you. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. I will now present the result for the first quarter of 2008 and before, as mentioned by Frédéric, answering any questions with members of the Executive Committee, which are sitting next to me.

I will begin with a few comments on the financial climate over the quarter. First quarter of 2008 was marked by a deepening of the financial crises and also growing signs that the U.S. economy was slipping into recession. We also saw dislocation of the credit markets, which posed significant fluctuation in certain figure over the first quarter of '08 results as you would see. Nevertheless, in a very challenging environment, the group posted strong commercial performances which illustrate its capacity to bounce back. For example, our retail banking network in France, outside France, as well as the Financial Services had 7 million additional individual customers on a like-for-like basis including acquisitions, so you compare to last year, representing an 11.5% increase on a like-for-like basis. At the end of March, Société Générale Group had 30 million individual customer worldwide.

Regarding Corporate and Investment Banking, it posted sturdy commercial performance given the environment and so overall activity levels in the first quarter confirm the quality and the strength of our business franchises.

As we already mentioned, in the first quarter the Group took control of Rosbank, the leading privately owned banking network in Russia, with around 600 branches. Société Générale since mid-February owns 50% plus one share of the capital of Rosbank. And as you know, we've launched a public offering to increase up to a maximum of 57.8% of the capital of Rosbank this quarter.

Frédéric has already mentioned another important event in the first three months of this year, the successful capital increase for €5.5 billion, which has been let's say 1.8 times over-subscribed. The capital increase will enable the Group to continue its development in businesses and markets with potential and of course to strengthen its financial structure.

In the wake of the exceptional fraud uncovered at the start of the year, the Group has also launched a plan to strengthen control procedures and the Special Committee put in place by the Board of Director will present its final report on the subject ahead of the AGM due on May 27th.

Finally, technically, let's say, I would like to point out that the figures in the presentation have not been restated for the accounting consequences of the fictitious operation recorded in 2007 on unauthorized and concealed market activities. However, these restated figures are available in the supplementary data.

If you move now to slide 5, which shows some graphs illustrating that there is a strong deterioration that we have seen in the credit spreads until mid-March. I would like to point out notably the deterioration, which has been seen on the American asset-backed securities was spread each peak or high across all vintages and ratings on both RMBS and CMBS.

The financial crises also continued to spread to other asset classes, namely European asset-backed securities, we have that on the top right of the slide, which had previously been relatively unaffected compared to American asset-backed securities and also at the bottom of the slide on corporate counterparts, as well as financial institutions.

In this extremely volatile climate, a disconnection was observed also between cash instruments and indices, which resulted in significant basis risk. Spreads widened significantly between 1st Jan and in March to levels which had been – never been – never seen since the start of the financial crisis. Also as the trading values of the hedge and on the underlying assets are not in perfect correlation the banks using indices to hedge their exposure to risk find themselves exposed to high basis risk, which had an impact on this quarter results.

The bailout of Bear Stearns in mid-March and the massive intervention of the central banks dissipated fears of a systematic collapse, resulting in a trend reversal and certain spread tightening in the last few days of the quarter.

If we now move to slide 6; in this backdrop and despite the crisis, the Group posted satisfactory results in the first quarter '08. Note that the results are being compared to high reference base for the first quarter of '07. I remind you that in the first quarter last year the Group enjoyed a very dynamic commercial performance across all businesses and also especially in the financial markets, which were very supportive.

I would like to point out before dictating the main item of the P&L that the result for the first quarter of '08 contained several non-recurring items that I will comment on during the presentation. Additional write-downs seen through the exposure to U.S. residential mortgage sector through monoline insurers, write-downs on certain portfolios and on the positive side, the impact of the change in fair value of financial liabilities, and the mark-to-market value of our credit default swap portfolios. All these items, let's say, are summarized in the slide, page 44, and in the press release page 25.

If you look now to the main line of the P&L; revenues at the Group stood at €5.7 billion, down 8.6% on a like-for-like basis. This decline would have been 17.7% adjusted for the change in fair value of financial liabilities, which amounted to €523 million. The increase in operating expense was limited, up 3.4% on a like-for-like basis, reflecting two different trends. On one side the ongoing investments that we continue to convert in business and regions with high potential and on the other side with high control on operating expense in the day-to-day business. The cost/income ratio came out at 68.8%, which is up compared to the low base of comparison of last year; last year the cost/income was 61.2%.

On the cost of risk, the net allocation to provision rose to €598 million compared to 192 in the fiscal 2007. The major explanation of this increase comes from the Corporate and Investment Banking where we have to make provision of few debilitated accounts. Over the quarter, if we sum up the positive and negative non-recurring items, the total impact on the profit before tax amounts to 89 million euro positive and this includes €602 million pre-tax capital gain linked to the disposal of the Group of a 50% stake of Fimat due to the creation of Newedge. As we know, Newedge was established on the 2nd of Jan through the merger of Fimat and Caylon Financial. Note that this impact has a very limited impact on the Tier 1 of the Group because we have also to recognize in face of the – in front of this capital gain, €420 million of additional goodwill. So overall, when we look at the bottom-line, the net income stood at €1,096 million, down 23% compared to last year. The return on equity after tax came out at 16.5% for the quarter compared to 24.4% last year.

The increase in the risk-weighted assets under Basel I was at 15.8% on a like-for-like basis, resulting from sustained organic growth in retail businesses, the fact that the remediation launched by the Group in Asset Management has also some impact on the weighted assets and also the commitments of the Group to slow down the increase of the risk-weighted assets within the Corporate and Investment Banking.

The Group financial structure is solid. Our Tier 1 stood at 7.9% at the end of March. So core Tier 1 excluding PEL/CEL 11:36) and hybrid reached 6.8% and the total Tier 1 – total capital ratio reached 10.5% at the end of March.

Page 7, more detail on the growth in revenues by businesses. As I mentioned, this – the first quarter '08 was marked by solid commercial activity in a difficult environment. The Group revenues saw a decline by 8.6% and if we look more into detail, we have the French Networks, which posted a resilient performance with a 2% increase in revenues excluding PEL/CEL.

Retail banking activities outside France posted a very strong performance with a 22% increase on a like-for-like basis. Revenues at Financial Services continued to grow, increasing by 12.4% versus last year. And then moving to Asset Management, we had some significant impact of the crisis, but with the end of the remediation of assets held by the dynamic money market funds and so as we expect, we had negative net banking income this quarter, which has weighted on the performance of GIMs overall.
Nevertheless, looking at Private Banking and Securities Services, they had strong performances with an increase of respectively 12.8% for the Private Banking and 28.8% for Securities Services.

Lastly, in Corporate and Investment Banking there was a solid client-driven activity in a difficult climate. Trading revenues have continued to be impacted by the financial crises and by additional write-downs. So, overall revenues fell by 16.6% and note that if we were to exclude the fair value of financial liabilities, so the 523 million euro already mentioned, revenues at CIB would have fall by 44.5% as compared to last year.

Page 8; the Group cost/income ratio stood at 68.8% for the first quarter, versus, as I mentioned, a low level last year 61.2% where the market conditions were very supportive. On the one hand, there was deterioration of the cost/income ratios at the business lines affected by the crises, Asset Management, where as there is no revenues the cost/income is not relevant. CIB, where we've seen a cost/income ratio of 64% compared to 55.5% last year, mainly due to the fall in revenues.

On the other hand, the cost/income ratios of all other business line were kept under control. French Networks, retail banking outside France, Securities Services improved their cost/income ratio compared to last year. Financial Services and Private Banking managed to keep their cost/income ratio under control led by the ongoing investments that we are conducting in their developments.

The cost of risk on page 9 came out at 71 basis points this quarter, up compared to last year, which is where it stood at 26 basis points. I would like to point out that the level of cost of risk for this quarter is not representative of trends that we could expect for the full year as it includes high allocation linked to a few high consolidated accounts in CIB in the first quarter that should not be reiterated in the coming quarter.

Looking more into detail, the French Networks have a cost/income ratio which is slightly down compared to last year by 28 basis points of the risk weighted assets. The cost of risk of the International Retail Banking was 61 basis points of CWA compared to 54 basis points last year. This cost of risk is in line with the normal level we would expect in such a business given the current mix. I'll remind you that we have arranged for the cost of risk of the Retail Banking outside France between 60 to 80% and let's say, of course, this quarter we have seen the inclusion of Rosbank which has a cost of risk of around 115 basis point and if you were to exclude Rosbank to compare – like-for-like basis compared to last year so cost of risk at Retail Banking outside France would have been 61 basis points.

So an increase of 15 in the cost of risk of Financial Services to 105 bps compare to 91 bps last year due to the integration of recent acquisition, namely the two acquisition we've made in Brazil, Banco Pecúnia and Banco Cacique as well as a small acquisition we made in Greece. And mechanically also, we have already communicated on that. The business mix is moving towards more consumer loans, in particular in emerging market, leading to an increase of the cost of risk. This shift, however, is positive globally as it provide us additional growth and the cost of risk is considerably covered by the banking margin in these regions.

Lastly to comment on the CIB; I mentioned that we have €312 million net allocation linked to a few high derivative accounts, which are identified in appendices. These accounts represent €282 million of the 312 that we passed in the first quarter. As we mentioned, at this point of the cycle, we have not noticed any deterioration in credit risk of the whole portfolio but also, and it was mentioned in the previous quarter, we do no longer expect a reversal in the coming quarter.

Before turning to business performance, let me provide you an update on Basel II reform at Société Générale. So this slide contains the figure – initial figure regarding the application of the Basel II reform at the end of March for the Group as a whole. This is a complicated reform to analyze and so we plan to organize with you a meeting on the 25th of June to present in detail the consequences of the application of the Basel II reform on the Group and on its businesses, both in term of capital allocation, in term of profitability.

So the scope of application of the Basel II reform at Société Générale is based for the most parts on the use of internal methods. These are for credit risk while we are using internal ratings based advanced methodology, which cover 75% of our spending or for operational risk where we did use advanced measurement approach, which has an extensive coverage of the Group entities, almost 90%.

The French Banking Commission validated these methods at the end of 2007 and launched an additional mission in March '08 on operational risk in order to examine the methods used by the SocGen Group to integrate the impact of Eastern situation into the fraud and assess its relevance.

So at end of March '08, the reformer had resulted in a number of decline in the risk-weighted assets under Basel II compared to Basel I, despite taking into account the new regulation requirement with regard to operational risk, which integrates the impact of the fraud uncovered last January.

So in total, we have a decrease of the risk-weighted assets by 5.3% at the end of March resulting entirely from the reduction that we have seen in credit risk which has declined by 18.3%. As a result the Tier 1 ratio under Basel II increased 11bps compared to the Basel I at 8.0%.

The difference is that there is two impact, on one side let's say the decrease in risk-weighted assets leads to a positive impact on the Tier 1 of 43bps, and as you know on the other side, we have to deduct from the Tier 1 some elements, which were previously either not existing or been deducted from the Tier 1 Basel II, and this deduction had an impact of minus 32 bps at the end of March. So, again, I give you a meeting on the 25th of June to discuss the Basel II reform more into detail.

Moving to page 13 on the businesses starting with the French Networks; the French Networks posted moderate business growth in a very difficult climate at the start of the year, which was marked on one side by the crises in central markets and of course by the growth posted by Société Générale. The fraud and the intense media coverage attracted – waited on the recruitments of new individual customers in Société Générale Network; there has been no impact on business customer at this stage.

However, it's important for us; there has been almost no effect on the customer attrition which remains stable for this quarter. We are regularly conducting surveys and we made – we conducted one of these surveys in March and these surveys has illustrated that Société Générale image remains one of the best in France.

Asking to non-clients which bank they would choose, should they have to change, Société Générale is one of the most attractive banks, ranking fourth among all banks and number one among non-insurance banks with almost 50% of positive answers saying yes, or yes maybe. Also, the same survey conducted towards Société Générale customers show that 90% of our customers are confident in our strengths.

If now we look at individual customers, the number of personal current accounts continues to grow, even if it was, as I mentioned already at a moderate pace – at a more moderate pace than in the previous quarter, we would have 21,700 new net openings in the first three months of this year compared to 39,000 last year.

Looking at the change in savings, let's say we have seen that our customer – our retail customers have this as a standard behavior when they face uncertainties that they're trying to move to products combining liquidity and very limited risk in term of retail. As a result, there was also a 4.8% increase in regulated savings deposits excluding PEL, which continue to see outflows and this was mainly driven by liquidity . There was a modest increase in sight deposits by 2.6% compared to the first quarter, '07.

On the life insurance side, inflows fell sharply as compared to last year, down by almost 28% at 2.1 billion and compared – if we compare our performance with the banking insurance market, the decline for the G11 was minus 18%.

Nevertheless, what we have seen in March is that the gap in term of waiting settlements has almost disappeared as we have launched a campaign in March that will end in May, pushing let's say for attractive rates of an immunity contract with a certain portion of synergies in term of investments.

In housing loans, the group continues to focus its pricing efforts on the most promising customer segments given the gradual lending of the property sector and ongoing high level of competition. Housing loans issuance of 3.8 billion in Q1 '08 was stable compared to last year, but we improved margins.

If you turn to business customer, the markets post strong performances with a high number of relationships established with high quality SMEs, almost nine of which were new SMEs, were won this quarter. So a slight decrease compared to last year, but it was a two year peak. We have seen a 2.6% increase in the outstanding sight deposits compared to last year, and a 13% increase in term deposits.
Regarding lending, that was also down in performance with a 15.5% increase in outstanding operating loans and a 14.7% increase in outstanding investment loans compared to the last year.

If you turn to page 14, we have a breakdown of revenues. You can see that in the backdrop, revenues were up 2% excluding the impact of PEL/CEL provision. The PEL/CEL provision has different movements compared to last year as we have to allocate 5 million additional this quarter, while last year we recorded a reversal of €26 million. Splitting, let's say, these revenues between fees and net interest margin, there was a moderate growth of 1.3% in income from fees and commission compared to last year and finally due to the fall of financial commission by minus 7.3%. This decrease is linked to the decline in commission on both investments in mutual funds as well as life insurance products, and also with the reduction in market orders, given the weakness of the financial market.

If you look at service commissions, the increase was 4.5% and we've seen a very good increase in the use of different banking services, specialty insurance, non-life insurance and payment services. This increase reflects the strengths and the developments of our customer base in both networks; Société Générale and Crédit du Nord.

If you look at net interest income at the French Networks, increase was 2.6% excluding PEL/CEL compared to last year driven mainly by the increases seen in outstanding deposits and loans. The interest margin reached 2.41 – 2% point 41 basis points, down 21 bps compared to last year and 5 bps compared to the fourth quarter of 2007.

The effort of our one year due to on one side a continued shift in the balance sheet with an increase of loans, which is higher than deposit; it explains 14 bps of the total. And of course in this quarter, we've registered, let's say a 50bps increase in the regulating deposits after the 25 that we have seen in the 1st of August last year and this has an impact of minus 4 bps also on the margin.

On page 15, if you look at the full P&L of the network, we can say that the French Networks posted solid financial results this quarter. As we've seen net banking income increase by 2%, growth in operating expense remains under control at plus 1.4% compared to last year, and as a results the cost/income ratio fell by further 40 bps compared to the first quarter of '07, so 66.6% excluding PEL/CEL. I already commented on cost of risk which is slightly down compared to last year and so consequently the operating income rose by 1.8% compared to last year, excluding PEL/CEL. And return on equity after tax at the French Networks was 19.1% compared to 20.9% last year, excluding PEL/CEL.

For the full year, we do expect growth which will be lower than what we have registered in 2007 mainly for two major reasons. On one side, uncertainties about economic growth as well as financial markets which you have seen has weighted on the financial condition evolution in the first quarter. And secondly because it is likely that due to inflation rise, which, let's say, is difficult for us to price in rates or fees. It's likely that we have a further 25 bps increase of the regulated savings deposits on the 1st of August – on the next 1st of August.

If we move now to International Retail Banking, of course already mentioned, retail banking outside France did record this quarter the integration of Rosbank, which brought 2.8 million additional individual customers.

If you look at the performance, let's say, it was a very good first quarter in 2008 with a robust sales performance. The number of individual customers increased by 829,000 new individual customers over one year at constant structure, so almost 10.3% with strong performance registered in Romania, in Egypt, and in Morocco and Italy. You have the progression of customer deposits and loans, I will not comment on that, but it remains double-digit figure in line with what we had in mind for the trends in this division.

In order to take advantage of growth opportunities in the modernized markets, this division continues to step up investments in organic growths. Thus the density of the network was further increased with 347 branches opened over one year at constant structure, with Romania accounting for 188 additional branches, but also we mentioned that we did open additional 61 branches in Mediterranean Basin. At the end of March '08, the total number of branches of retail banking outside France stood at 3,422, including Rosbank. We do expect this branch's opening pace to continue in '08.
In terms of staff, the staff number increased by 3,140 at constant structure to keep pace with gross and accompanied development of the network.

As I mentioned already in February 2008, there could be a chance of majority shareholder in Rosbank, and so we have launched an effort to the minority shareholder which ran until – which was run until yesterday. And so, we will publish soon the final results of this offer.

Rosbank sits pretty consolidating our accounts in January 1st of '08. So we have 100% of the revenues, 100% of the costs, 100% of the provisions. But the instruments that we have retained to calculate as a contribution to the Group profit is 35%, so 20% for one month and a half, and 50% for the rest of the quarter.

Moving next page, let's say, putting the strategy of the Retail Banking division into perspective. As you know that our development model in this division combines targeted acquisition and organic investments and this has resulted in fast and profitable growth in recent years thereby concerning the status of this activity as a growth driver for the group.

We have major phases of this accelerated growth, which has been first the acquisition of BRD in Romania in 1999, KB in Czech Republic in '01, MIBank to complement NSGB at the end of '07, in 2006 the Group bought Splitska Banka in Croatia, and so lastly we took the control in mid-February of Rosbank, and this is a major step for this activity.

As we mentioned that in Russia, we're already active with BSGV and the tax audit, and the Rosbank operation, which announced a new stage in development in the spot market, even contributed a high economy growth, but where the use of banking services is still underdeveloped.

Organic investment has also kept pace with these acquisitions and since 2003, as you can see on those slides, that we opened 1,120 additional branches. This is more than the number of branches that came from acquisitions during the period. Investment in Romania was one of the large contributor to this opening of new branches accounting for 640 of the total of 1,120.

The application of this development strategy to regions with high growth potential for the banking industry and with economic potential has resulted in very strong commercial momentum, and as you can see, in 2003 outstanding deposits have increased by an average of almost 25% per year and outstanding loans are up by almost 35% per year, are doing so for the last four years. At the end of March 2008, International Retail Banking served 11.8 million individual customers compared to only 4.7 million at the end of 2003, so a multiplication by 2.5.

In term of financial results, you can see also that the NBI of International Retail Banking rose by 19.3% per year on average between 2003 and 2007. And despite the significant organic investments which I have just mentioned, this business, nevertheless, managed to improve its cost/income ratio by 3.4 points between 2003 and 2007 resulting in an increase in the operating income at a faster pace, almost 26% per year during the period.

Coming back to the first quarter results, International Retail Banking posted a sharp increase in their results. Revenues, as I mentioned, rose by 22.1% on the like-for-like basis driven mainly by strong performance achieved by Romania, Czech Republic and Egypt. The main structural effect has been, of course, the full consolidation of Rosbank. Rosbank revenues amounted to €183 million in the first quarter of '08.

Operating expenses increased by 14.7% compared to last year and this includes, as we mentioned on the quarterly basis, 6 percentage points, an increase by 6% linked to investment in the network development.

As a result, the cost income ratio was lower at 58.2%. 57.2 if you exclude Rosbank, so a decline compared to the cost income ratio of last year. I already commented the cost of freight with and without Rosbank and so as a result the return on equity after tax remained high at 33.8% in the first quarter of '08 compared, but was stable compared to last year.

If you move now to financial services on page 21 with the focus on the consumer credit business; consumer credit activities continued their strong development in the fiscal '08 driven by emerging countries. That was sustained at a 12.5% increase in new lending at €3 billion and as I said this was driven by strong performance that we seen in Russia, an increase by 59% of new business compared to last year. Poland, an increase by 95% and also Ukraine, an increase our notification by almost 2.6 times on the new business compared to last year.

New lending in France, Italy and Germany was stable compared to the first quarter of '07. Also, even if they were already consolidating in the second half of '07 compared to last year, we have to mention that we have the consolidation of Banco Cacique and Banco Pecunia in Brazil. They accounted for a new business of approximately €118 million this quarter or 6% of total new business.

Overall, the consumer credit outstanding were up by 15.4% compared to last year to €18.8 billion and this excludes the assets managed on behalf of the French retail networks, which amounted to €6.1 billion. The development strategy at the business side, which combines strong organic investments in emerging market and targeted acquisitions has stepped up since 2005, with the acquisition of Eurobank in Poland, Promek and SKT in Russia, and Banco Pecunia and Banco Cacique in Brazil.

We have also continued to create greenfield operation ever since in Turkey and Vietnam at the end of '07, and we have launched at the start of 2008 a subsidiary in Serbia. The business now presents in 25 countries, with strong position in both Western and Central and in Eastern Europe. So development strategy have led to dynamic progression in the business time in the recent year and this trend has continued in the first quarter with a 33% increase in revenues compared to last year, 15.9% over like-for-like basis. And the gross that you can see on the pie chart was driven by the emerging markets which posted the sharp increase in their contribution, with NBI doubling in absolute terms compared to last year and spending that today at 46% of the total compared to 31% one year earlier.

On page 22, moving to business finance and services, there was also in this division, this sub component of the financial services, a very good growth in leasing and also in fleet management. In leasing, I remind you that SG Equipment Finance is a leader in equipment finance in Continental Europe. And it posted an 11.3% increase in new lending to €2.2 billion compared to last year. The performance was driven by good activities in Northern and Central and Eastern Europe. At the end of March 2008, outstanding excluding factoring to that €17.6 billion up by 7.5% on a like-for-like basis over one year.

SG Equipment Finance is present in 23 countries worldwide. Operational vehicle leasing and fleet management continued also a sustained development with a 6.9% increase in the fleet management over one year at constant structure to 742,000 vehicles at the end of March. ALD Automotive which is present in 39 countries thus strengthened its position as European number two in term of fleet management.

If we move to page 23 on the financial results for financial services as a whole. The net income of financial services rose by 11.6% compared to last year at €154 million. Total net banking income at specialized financing increased by 12.5%. Operating expenses increased at a slightly slower pace, 12.1%, as a result of high level of global investment especially in consumer credit and to a certain extent in equipment finance.

The cost income ratio remained under control at the low level of 59.4%. The increase in net allocation of provisions reflect the growing weight of consumer activities in the SFS and the growing presence of emerging countries in which the cost of risk is higher but as already mentioned, which is easily covered by the margin.

If we have a focus on life insurance, the gross new setting influence in life insurance were down by 16.7% compare to last year to €2.3 billion in a challenging and very competitive financial environment. Against this backdrop, the share in unit-linked policies amounted to 15.5%, reflecting investor preference for our euro denominated contract. Mathematical provision rose by 3.9% on a like-for-like basis, of one year. Overall revenues in the insurance activity rose by 12.8% versus last year.

I propose you now to move to Global Investment Management and Services division. The mix performances in this core business continued on from the trends in H207 with Asset Management suffering from the liquidity crisis, while Private Banking and Security Services, performing very well.

I would like to start on page 25 and 26 with Asset Management. Asset Management continued to suffer the adverse effect of the liquidity crisis, which started last summer. So trend in outflows, which are started in the third quarter continued for both dynamic money market funds, which recorded outflows of 5.2 billion this quarter and CDOs managed by TCW, which recorded outflows of 4.8 billion this quarter.

In CDOs the outflows stem from the unwinding of the last market values CDOs in the western world, which have started in the third quarter of last year. I remind you that the collateral manager in this typology of CDO liquidates in the event of the deterioration the value of the security used as collateral below certain levels and this is what took place on this categories of CDOs over the last three quarters.

Note that the withdrawals of the CDOs does not have any impact let's say or in terms of losses of this revenue, but it is more let's say, a loss of opportunities of revenues on future commission in the future. We do estimate that the loss of revenues coming from management fees this quarter, amounted to approximately US$6 million for the CDOs.
We should point out that the outflows of total €10 billion have been partially offset by subscription to regular money-markets funds, which amounted to approximately €5 billion this quarter.

In total outflows, again in the first quarter amounted to minus €7.3 billion. On top of this outflows, market effects were negative for 23.5 billion and exchange rate affect negative for minus 7.7 billion. I remind you that this revenue which is of course in dollar represents 26% of the production under management at the end of March '08.

The total assets under management have again stood at €319.2 billion of assets excluding of course the assets managed by Lyxor Asset Management, which is consolidated in the equity division of the CIB, and Lyxor Asset Management had 72.5 billion of asset under management at the end of March.

Regarding dynamic money market assets, they amounted to 5.6 billion at the end of March compared to 11 billion at the end of December. And we should mention that these assets were made liquid for the most part with less than 10% of the assets invested in asset-backed securities.

If we continue on page 26, let's say, we should mention that again the backdrop for the liquidity crisis, most of Asset Management companies have been safe since August 2007, with respect to these drawdown demands from their money market funds. And again -- was one of the leader from these market segments with a very high market share of approximately 20% before the start of the crisis.

The Group has already announced in the fourth quarter that it has taken the decision to support the liquidity of certain mutual funds in the interest of its clients and in the respect equality between unit holders. To this end in the fourth quarter, it put in place liquidity buffers, rapid disposal means in the market and through SGAM bond I remind you that we mentioned that as SGAM bond had €4.4 billion of assets in the balance sheet at the end of December.

In the first quarter of 2008 there were further disposal, mainly to make to funds as liquid as possible given both the ongoing deterioration of the credit markets and also the risk of the spillover of the crisis as well as to be able to cope with withdrawals. The sales were carried out in the market to the Group both Société Générale Corporate and Investment Banking and the corporate center, which purchased in particular the asset housed by SGAM bond at the end of the '07. The disposals were carried out at the price fixed by models integrating observational market prices, spread analysis, the rating and maturity of the securities, and each party, again the corporate center validated the prices.

Overall assets purchased and held by the Group as part of managing the crisis amounted to at the most to 7.4 billion housed in the same portfolio at SG CIB and 3.8 billion at the corporate center, so a total 11.2 billion. The type of underlying assets in the portfolios are break down and the rating of these assets are covered by two slides that we'll find in appendices at the end of the presentation.

As a result of these assets disposal from SGAM to other party of the Group, SGAM booked as a negative item in net banking income, minus €274 million coming mainly from losses, minus 270, and write-downs minus 4. On top of these losses, SGAM also booked minus €60 million linked to seed money which we also disclosed in the previous quarter. I do believe that at the end of March 2008, the measures taken to reduce the sensitivity of portfolios managed by SGAM for third parties are almost complete and that dynamic money market funds now are for the most part being managed.

If we move to page 27, regarding Private Banking, we should mention that in the challenging environments and marked by the liquidity crisis, but also by the announcement of the Board of Société Group, SG Private Banking generated very satisfactory documentaries with net new money of €0.4 billion this quarter compared to 2 billion last quarter – in the first quarter of '07. So, training outflow that we've seen at the end of February was reversed during March with net inflows of €600 million in March reflecting the confidence of our clients and prospects after the success of the capital increase, as you can see on the bottom right of the slide. The market impact and for any change impact for the quarter were unfavorable reflecting the minus €4.6 billion and minus 1.4 billion.

We should also mention that this quarter SG Private Banking realized or consolidated Canadian Wealth Management, a small boutique in Private Banking, Calgary which contributed 0.4 billion of asset under management to the business line.

As a result, asset under management of SG Private Banking stood at €71.7 billion compared to 76.9 at the end of 2007, as I mentioned mainly coming from the forex and negative market movement. These assets mentioned do not include, of course, the assets held by customers of the French network with investable assets of euro 150,000 which accounted for €112 billion at the end of March.

If you look at the financial performance of SG Private Banking, the gross margin was very strong at 115 bps this quarter compared to 111 in the first quarter of 2007. This increase is due to the ongoing development of the credit activities as the credit activity was more cash positioned at – in our customer base, and the treasury activities which all took advantage of the pressure on interest rates and spread widening as a result of the liquidity crisis.

It is important to notice that the impact of the current economic condition has not altered the ambition of the business planned for 2010 that Frédéric mentioned in early February, i.e. positively doubling the return on – the gross impact on income compared to its level in 2006. The division – the business line will also continue to strengthen its sales force. We have increased by 145 different officer compared to last year, strengthened our continued targeted acquisitions and also continued to be one of the most dynamic franchise in Europe as well in international markets, mainly Asia.

On page 28, I focus on the Securities Services, which is not there including the recent creation of Newedge. For SG SS, assets under custody rose to €2,731 billion at the end of March, at 11.6% compared to last year. This includes the impact on one side of the acquisition of Capitalia securities activities in the last day of March as well as a successful migration of the Pioneer Funds in Luxembourg, it was the last stage of the acquisition we made18 months ago of Pecúnia Banco, which . So these two operations did contribute 150 billion to the assets under custody, so the underlying growth is approximately 5% over the quarter.
In terms of assets under administration, it reached €499 billion at the end of the quarter at 28% compared to last year and again, this includes 120 billion coming from Pioneer and Capitalia.

Looking at Boursorama, we're seeing an environment where we are seeing a downturn in stock market indices. The number of executed orders at Boursorama fell by a little bit less 12% compared to last year. However, it is important to mention that the banking arm of Boursorama has been increasingly successful since its launch, with 5,700 new bank accounts opened over the quarter, which is almost double than the figure realized by Boursorama last year. And Boursorama had, at the end of March around 68,000 accounts for the banking operation.

Moving to Newedge, so as I mentioned, which has been trading on the second of Jan, the new entities resulting from the merger of Fimat and Calyon has been achieving a sustained activity with 431 million executed transactions for the quarter, 462 million contracts cleared. And so in listed derivatives, it's undergoing the regular growth that's confirmed its position as one of the world leader in execution and clearing, and as you can see on the table, ranked number three per Futures Commission Merchants in terms of account deposit, published at the end of February.

Page 29 has the P&L of GIMS, like I said already there were mixed performance at GIMS with asset management significantly impacted by the liquidity crisis. So NBI of the division came out at €597 million down 42.4% on a like-for-like basis compared to last year. A negative growth of credit income which came mainly from the losses registered by SGAM; the other business is performing pretty well. I will not comment all the details; you have the figure under here.

Moving to Corporate and Investment Banking, page 31, we told you that the revenues at Corporate and Investment Banking for the first quarter '08 were marked by impacts again of the credit market crisis. The total revenues of the SG CIB came out at €1,563 million, down 16.6% compared to last year, which again was a very high level of comparison. I remind that it was almost a record level for SG CIB in the first quarter of '08.

In short and before determining each business line individually, I would like to point out that the equities, franchise registered very well over the quarter, as did financing and advisory arm despite the lack of activity in the market, and the fixed income division continue to suffer from the effect of the credit market crisis on the trading side, the client-driven activity performed pretty well.
The 20% fall in the account driven revenues of the CIB versus last year to 971 million euro nevertheless reflected the strong resilience of our franchises in an unfavorable market environment.

Trading activities, and I will comment on this point, made another negative contribution and there was, I say, three buckets of impact. The first one is a write-down linked to the crisis in the U.S. real estate residential markets, the second one comes from the credit market dislocation and this was partly offset or totally offset by the mark-to-market under CDS and financial liabilities.

Starting with the first bucket, so the write-downs resulting from the crisis in the U.S. residential market, you can see that we have had additional €350 million write-downs on the portfolio of energy CDOs, I will comment on that later; additional €203 million for counterparty risks on monoline insurers, and also minus €43 million write-down from the RMBS portfolio.

The second bucket comes from the dislocation of the credit markets and the extension of the crisis to new asset classes especially in Europe. And as you can see we have – this has led us to book in SG CIB results in the first quarter '08, minus €166 million of write-downs on the European ABS portfolio sold by SGAM, and further €417 million in losses and write-downs, approximately two share losses and one share write-downs on our portfolio of exotic credit derivative.

These items were almost entirely offset by significant positive movements including the positive impact of the mark-to-market value of CDS for €743 million, and as I already mentioned also, the positive item of €523 million coming from such additional on credit risk on financial liabilities revaluation at fair value during the quarter.

As you can, as you have seen in the first slide, credit supply continued to erode in April. It is, it was important for us to mention that the mark-to-market on the CDS, which generates volatility in our revenues has almost been erased at the end of April post the .

On page 32, if we move to each business line, market conditions in the equities harming the first quarter remained very challenging with difficult market alignment and were marked also by very high volatility and short increase in correlation. Whether equity in the finance book is a very strong client-driven performance which proved that its franchise has remained intact. Q1 '08 was a transition period for the trading activities and I remind that we have voluntarily reduced some stress test limits and some volumes on competitive operation. And so we have also strengthened the controls post lien coverage of the whole.

Again with backdrop, equities posted NBI of €734 million, down 3% compared to the fourth quarter and 31% compared to the first quarter last year which was a record level. If we do exclude the change in fair value of financial validity which represented €200 million impact, the net banking income came out at €534 million, down 48.5% on the like-for-like basis compared to last year.

So account-driven investments which amounted to €367 million for the quarter, down 36% compared to Q1 and 15% compared to Q4, quite solid, and account for the solid contribution from flow products especially EPS in which mix arrangement in Europe with a market share of 27%. We should note it also that the performance in structured products was flat compared to what we have seen in the fourth quarter in terms of new business.

Lyxor as I mentioned the outstanding of the asset management of Lyxor. Lyxor asset management posted also very high inflows of €6.3 billion during the quarter. On the trading side for the quarter, the revenues came out at €167 million, stable compared to the fourth quarter of '07 and done significantly on the very high level of first quarter '07.
As I mentioned already, this reflects the group's deliberate decisions to produce track estimates and reduce non-productivity as well of course, as well as the less favorable market condition.

If we move to Financing and Advisory, the division which is very well in low market volumes as the middle of the crisis. The total revenues amounted to €980 million for the quarter. It is important to notice that it benefited from the positive impact of the mark-to-market value of the Canadian footswap which accounted for €743 million during the quarter. The account driven revenues came out at €207 million compared to 359 last year, a decrease by 25%.

This quarter revenues also included a €44 million write-down on the portfolio of investment great transaction in the right thing including a write-down of 24 million for the LBO portfolio. This write-down based on conservative assumption and we have some detail in the appendices, was booked on the portfolio of LBO and syndication which account for approximately €0.9 billion at the end of March compared to 1.2 billion at the end of '07 and we have applied a discount of approximately 8% on the book which was there before the crisis.

Overall, note that the performance of the division were generated in a difficult environment with a general downturn volumes, which mainly affected primary issuance in euros, bonds and shares, syndication markets and of course LBO markets. Against this backdrop DCM business of Société Générale. We managed to complete several significant transactions which had always strengthened, as you can see on the slide, its market share in euro denominated bond issue on previous quarter with a market share of 5% and the top five positions, which is our aim in terms of market positioning. Just to give you example, SG CIB was a joint book runner in Boursorama, Texmart and the Kingdom of Spain.

Lastly, the structure of finance activity also confirmed their strength in particular commodities and infrastructure financing. Several large operations were carried out throughout the quarter. For example SG CIB was the arranger for the organization of the coal pre-export facility for SUEK the leading Russian coal producer. This transaction also involved several of our business lines demonstrating the quality of our cross-selling model.

If we move now to the fixed income currencies and commodities division, it posted a solid client driven activities level in very unfavorable market conditions. However, as already mentioned, trading was affected by further write-downs and losses.

Total revenues of the business came out at minus €151 million and if we have to exclude the change in fair value of financial liabilities, which represented €323 million for hitch during the quarter, revenues came out at minus €474 million. As I already mentioned, the quarter was marked by good client-driven activity and negative contribution from credit.

With regard to client-driven activities, activity level was solid with the record performance in flow products as you can see on the slide. Fixed income, currency, and credit flow business increased by 26% compared to the fourth quarter and 83% compared to the first quarter of '07. But of course, we have seen a slower activity in the structured rate product markets and an almost non-existent credit structure product markets. Overall client-driven activity came out at €327 million, down 8% compared to the fourth quarter of '07, but up almost 20% compared to the first quarter of '07.

Trading activity posted a negative contribution with net banking income of minus €801 million due to the deterioration of market condition marked by the sharp widening of credit spreads and high volatility. I may not again detail elements I mentioned at the beginning. But you should – I should mention that they account for €1,179 million negative.

So you can see that apart from these items, which are also important, the business was able to benefit from a strong performance in further activity and also a strong progression in flow rates trading activities during the quarter.

If we now move to let's say each bucket of write-offs that I mentioned at the beginning. On the un-hedged CDO portfolio in the U.S. residential mortgage sector, you can see on the table that the gross and net exposure of the AAA super senior tranches of CDOs totaled €4.4 billion at end of March compared to 4.9 billion at the end of '07.

So foreign exposure is not only linked to the change in the euro-dollar exchange rate, but also to the start of the amortization of some of the managed CDOs. Also we should mention that due to an early repayment and also default on some underlying assets, attachment points can slightly compare to end of '07, but generally remain at the same level.

With the change in the market environments, we have adjusted the assumption underpinning our valuation method by increasing income loss rate of 2005, 2006 and 2007 vintage to respectively 10% for 2005, about 9% at the end of '07, 25% income loss for the vintage 2006 it was previously 23% and 27% income loss for the vintage 2007, it was previously 25% at the end of '07.

This corresponds to a scenario of global loss for the entire industry through the – through the U.S. residential mortgage sector of U.S. $385 billion by the end of '07, the scenario was a global losses of U.S. $355 billion.

The results of this simulations, the write-down levels sort of retain, remain superior to the level of ABX indices, which we can see at the end of March. To, let's say, adjust for the appreciation of this new scenario, this has led us to carry additional write-downs for €350 million for the quarter. On top of the 1,250 billion, which we already booked during 2007. As a result, our net exposure on the financial debt senior tranches of CDO came out at 2.9 billion at the end of March, this correspond to an average write-down rate of 34% of the nominal amount of this tranches compared 25% at the end of 2007.

Moving to the monoline on page 36, so the gross exposure to monoline insurers tends from the financial guarantees that we receive from the insurers to hedge certain assets. Given the change in interest rate spreads in the first quarter, the estimated amounts which could become due to the Group from monoline guarantees rose from 1.9 billion at the end of '07 to 2.4 billion at the end of March. I remind you that evaluation methods used for measuring the fund, especially for underlying assets into the U.S. residential mortgage sector, is the same as the one used for the unhedged CDOs.

Net of this 2.4 billion exposure, we bought protection from banks, which are deductible from the gross exposure and this protection are stable at €0.6 billion at the end of March. Thus the net exposure of Société Générale Group increased from 1.3 billion at the end of '07 to 1.8 billion at the end of March.

While looking at the significant progress made in stabilizing certain monoline insurers over the quarter, we have chosen to maintain a cautious stance with a coverage rate of 60% of the exposure, which would approve our main uses. This is a very tough scenario, it is from one side the stress on underlying assets was actually realized and on the other side, in the event of the immediate and simultaneous default of all the monoline insurance company. So as a result, after the 900 million write-down in the fourth quarter '07 recorded by the group, we passed additional €203 million write-down which increased our coverage to a total of €1.1 billion.

On page 37 let me tell the exotic credit derivative exposure that we do carry. This exotic credit derivative activity is first of all account-driven activity, which is based on selling to clients securities index on the credits of an ABS portfolios. By purchasing this index securities, this is equivalent investor of selling the credit protection to Société Générale on tranches of ABS portfolio. And this is a term business and we don't want to retain the position, we have to hedge this position generically in our accounts. And so to do that we use several forms of interaction to limit our directional exposure to credit, we manage the position and double the hedge. So we do that through three ways; first of all by purchasing the portfolio from running ABS, second, by trading on the relevant indices, ABX, CMBX, also by adjusting the amount of protection sold to clients.
So changes in credit spreads are nevertheless liable to change in delta of the position and consequently the hedge must be permanently adjusted, this is what we call the dynamic hedge management.

As we stated at this top of the presentation, there where exceptionally large movements in U.S. and European credit spreads during the quarter and these movements affected the delta of the exhausted credibility position and also generated business risk, which will be entering assets held and the index hedges, I mentioned that the cash business will be exactly in the same magnitude than the indices during the quarter.

The management of this position as a result and of the business position coming from these movements – different movements from the indices and the cash resulted in losses of €470 million over the quarter. The net portfolio exposure at the end of March was short credit for 1.8 billion in equivalent five-year bonds. The slide also give you in footnotes the size of the portfolio of the underlying assets. As a conclusion to this activity, note that the directional position is limited, the exceptional spread movement in the first quarter '08 presenting an unprecedented base moment between cash and industry which explains a part of the losses, and lastly the quality of the underlying portfolio is not in doubt as it is 98% comprised of AAA rated businesses.

If you move now to page 38 on the full P&L of SG Corporate and Investment Banking, the results let's say reflect an extremely difficult market environment in page two on the trading side and as I have already explained, revenues were marked by substantial non-recurring items and I will not detail there again.

Operating expenses were down by minus 4.2% compared to the first quarter of '07. We should mention that the ongoing increase in staff number in the first quarter '08, plus 12% compared to last year, which reflects first of all the investment we made on the franchise in H1 07 as well as also the strengthening of the control procedure that we have conducted since the un-coverage of the fraud. So this strengthening or increased investment was partially offset by the decline in performance-linked bonuses.

The increase in the cost income also was slightly high at 64% compared to a low level of 55.5%, but this is entire due to the fall in revenues. I already commented the cost of risk over the quarter, which is in only two or three rigid accounts and the absence of reversal of old provisions. And so other results, net income was down 79%, €139 million corresponding to return on equity after tax at 9.4% for the quarter.

The risk weighted assets of SG CIB increased by 10.3% over one year; I remind you that we've slowed down the growth of the risk weighted assets, which stood at 26% on a like-for-like basis at midyear last year.

As a conclusion on page 40, revenues for the first quarter '08 as already mentioned by Frédéric, reflects the resilience of the group's franchises and its capacity to bounce back after an exceptionally serious incident. In a very difficult market environment the net income came out at €1,096 million, down by 23% compared to last year which was a high comparative base, especially in the Corporate and Investing Banking division.

The contribution of the retail banking business in France and outside France as well as a financial services to net income was very satisfactory and was up on the first quarter '07. And so this is very strong positive side. The contribution from GIMS was very much impacted by the latest negative impact of the recondition of assets in dynamic money market funds, but as I already mentioned both private banking, custody, Newedge will do well in this environment.

Lastly, Corporate and Investment Banking continue to be heavily impacted by the financial crisis, but its franchisees resisted well and in very difficult condition. The contribution of the corporate center was exceptionally high due of course to the capital gain on Fimat. So these results our strong sign and also the Group benefits from a base study financial situation as illustrated by Q1 ratio of 7.9% under Basel I, and 8.0% under Basel II.

We have the first question from Mr. Kian Abouhossein, JPMorgan. Sir please go ahead.

Hi. Can you hear me? Yes, hi. I have few questions, the first one is related to short correlation position, can you give me the gross mark-to-market that you took on the equity derivative correlation book ex provisions, excluding provisions that you might have taken against it? We've seen a slowdown in numbers in terms of the markets in Europe, but I am quite interested how you see that part of the business developing. I think you mentioned it's related to certain corporates or counterparties, just trying to understand what kind of provision is this? What is it related to? And lastly, if you could just tell me what your year-end outstanding number of shares are? Thank you, sorry – end of first quarter outstanding shares are? Thank you.

So, Kian good afternoon. I propose that Jean-Pierre will answer the question on the equity derivative credit products as well as the provision in CIB and then I will take the question on the number of shares at the end of the quarter. Jean-Pierre?

Yes Kian, well we don't disclose the detail of our profitability within our equity derivatives book it is fair to say it has been said that the correlation during the quarter specifically on Asia underlying was higher and that a certain number of banks, which were all involved in very similar transactions have suffered from the higher correlation, illiquidity of the market. We had an impact for us, which was not negligible, but which was well-managed basically and which we felt was not worth mentioning in specific detail. This being said, we feel that correlations today are at a quite high level and represent still, and maybe even more, quite an attractive asset.

On your second question about the structured-products business and the outlook. First of all, we mentioned that our production of structured products has been relatively stable compared to the first quarter. That does not so translate into P&L as part of our structured-product production has been down basically with transactions, which are impacted by the day-one IAS rule and for which we don't recognize immediately the P&L. But in terms of economic figures if you want, we were stable last year's Q4, which we felt was a quite reasonable performance.

Our outlook for structured product is actually less bearish than the one you have in your latest report. We feel that while on the retail side there could be some kind of slowdown in the current environment because clearly retail clients invest less into equity or equity-structured products when the environment is less favorable on the equity market. There is a stronger push from individual clients, which are not only hedge funds on one side, but more specifically pension fund and large asset managers with whom we have contracted non-negligible transaction; it's an understatement. And where we see a quite strong a potential. So in the short term, one can expect that the retail client business we will probably be slower, but that does not represent a major P&L impact as most of the retail activity these days is done on the request for corporate basis, where you have extremely competitive costs, which are given in a small margin. And we feel it will be compensated, at least in our case, more than compensated by the additional business. So medium term, we feel as we said during our capital increase that the clients or business revenues and specifically on the equity-derivatives side could grow at a rate which we expect and specifically for structured product, if I give you a wide range to be safe between 5 to 15% equity with a 2010 horizon.

On the third question as far as the corporate provisions are concerned, we never disclose, of course, for which client or which contracts we took provision, but we have said that for two or three specific files this quarter we took what we feel are quite prudent provision. But we feel these transactions are very specific, not linked to the current credit environment and as Didier mentioned, the outlook on our portfolio outside of this transaction is unchanged. And if we put aside this transaction we have no reason to change our current outlook in terms of overall medium-term cost of risk. For the last question I hand over back to Didier.

Thank you Jean-Pierre. So this is one of the most difficult questions. You have for the EPS that says the average number on slide 71 for the end of the quarter our total number of share. We had 583 million share at the end of March, sorry. Okay. Thank you very much. Very helpful.

Thank you. Good afternoon. Hi, it's Chris Malmer from Goldman's. A few questions, if I could start on the investment bank.
