Okay, fine. Just to answer the last two questions and then I will hand over to Jean-Pierre. For the seed money it is 16, 16 not 60, so there is 16 million euro losses on the seed money again. Regarding Rosbank, the one is we – I mentioned, let's say this is based on the normative equity, first of all, for the thing that Rosbank is not working let's say with the full benefit of its local capitalization, under our standard let's say we do allocate 50% of core Tier 1 of equity. So, I think there's not equity to calculate the revenues. And also for example Rosbank has part of its activity, which has been tabled in the custody business because of the activity just, you know, to take an example of the custodian business in retail banking outside France are now let's say under this provision of the custody business and with in jeans and so we have an analytical let's say breakdown of part of the revenues also to other businesses. So this is an explanation why that as the run rate you are effectively seeing that Rosbank appears to be slightly low compared to what you can see in its local reporting. I'll now hand over to Jean-Pierre on the question you had on the fixed-income revenues and as well as equity credit derivatives.

Bonjour, Chris. So on the fixed-income side, if I am a little bit extreme in case that we take everything which is losing, we have only what is making money. So – but your calculation is correct. If we take the exceptional item or at least what we characterize as exceptional item, the NBI for the quarter is around €705 million. So, part of these revenues are made of client revenues and the client revenues compared to the first quarter '07 are up 20%. So, that's the performance, which we feel is adequate in the environment, which was clearly overall a bit tough but as we said, we had quite a strong performance of our flow business. The flow business has increased by 83% versus Q1, '07, which is a business that we have developed for the past few years and the work which has been done by the team has brought quite a good result and the environment has been as such that there has been much less competition as well by banks and the spreads both on rates and credit were wider which was very supportive for the flow business which basically benefited from wider spreads in terms of market.

The second item, which explain good performance of the activity was that the books where initially on the trading side, outside of the sales side, were initially positioned being loan protection at the end of the first – at the last – fourth quarter of 2007, which helped as well especially on the flow trading side. And finally on our treasury business, we had quite a good performance as well. We were up 37% versus Q1, '07 there on a steeper curve and more market opportunities as well. So net-net, a good performance but I would not characterize the underlying performance of the fixed-income business ex exceptional to remain at €700 million, far from that, for the other quarters and the run rate should be more the run rate we had last year plus a few percent basically.

On your question on our structured-credit portfolio, your assumption is for a large extent correct. Most of the hedges we have detailed in the slide, on the slide 37, in the footnotes are for cash and we adjust our delta hedge for indices basically. So the initial hedges were made buying cash CMBS and we mentioned that we have 10.8 billion of CMBS, which are mostly U.S. CMBS. We have 4.5 billion of RMBS, breakdown that we – we could give you that – we have basically 1.4 billion of prime, we have 1 billion of subprime, and 2.2 billion of mid-prime. And as I mentioned on the U.S. ABS we have 98% of the cash assets, which are rated AAA basically. On the European ABS, we have 100% of assets which are rated AAA and we have 2.5 billion of those, 1.4 billion of European RMBS and outside of that roughly 590 million of UK RMBS and 280 million of Spanish RMBS. But as I said, all of those are AAA assets. That I think should answer your questions.

Okay. Thank you very much. May I just follow up, while I've got you on the line, just – we're hearing from some of your peers that when it comes to the basis risk, they are mostly concerned about the discrepancy between index and cash movements in the U.S. RMBS space and related securities and less so on the CMBS side. I was just wondering whether you would agree with that. And the second follow-up question would be, back to the asset-management division, if I then add back in the two negative one-offs in that division, so the 274 and the 16 million, it still seems as if the margin is down to a record low in asset management. I was just wondering whether there's anything there, obviously the composition seems to be improving with some of the money-market assets disappearing. So I was just wondering why the margin would be that low. Thank you.

On your first question, the basis risk, I think that we have seen a basis movement. As I said, we have initially put up the hedges by using the cash market and we adjust our delta hedge by using the index market. And we are seeing a basis risk on the RMBS side, but also on the CMBS side, which has been overreacting on the widening of the spread basically reaching roughly 300 basis points on the index side and the cash moved less to a certain extent and afterwards, narrowing quite sharply – in a very sharp short squeeze. And basically the – we feel that the index market, derivative market has a higher volatility because it's more liquid and hence as the market tends to basically – or the profitable players tend to hedge in the same way, it just pushes the derivative hedges hence creating this basis risk when we hedge our negative gamma or negative basically of the portfolio.
On the question on the gamma, I will let Philippe Collas answer. Very quickly I think this is also linked to the reduction that we booked in performance fees and...
Exactly. It is mainly coming from performance fees – we had less performance fees than last year and we think to the market effect.
And also as, I mentioned also, we do estimate that the outflows or the unwinding of the CDOs or so called in euros revenues this quarter and weighted on the margin.
Thanks a lot. That's very helpful.
You're welcome. Next question?
Next question is from Mr. Maxence Le Gouvello, Morgan Stanley. Sir, please go ahead.

Yeah. Good afternoon. My question would be on the French retail. First you mentioned that you launched life insurance campaigns this March. Is it possible to have a feedback of how you are performing? Second element is regarding the strong performance of the loan side on the SMEs. Can you please quantify – could you please give us some feeling of where this growth is coming from, which part is long-term investments, and because it's the second quarter, to which we have such a kind of growth on the SMEs. And if that's the case, is your new joint venture between the investment banking and the retail that you put in place two years ago, is giving you some really strong potentials? And if we can have also the – an idea of the return on equity of the SMEs, that would be great.

Maxence, I will let Jean-François answer to your two questions. I can already mention that on the return on equity on SMEs, we do not disclose this figure. So – and this is the end of the of the question.
Thank you, Didier.

Yes. Regarding the campaign on insurance life starting 1st of March, we have good result as we have – as the same result that in March . Also, we have do better than the market in March. After – we can say a very bad month in February, just after the Kerviel crisis. And so we are continuing in April. I don't know yet the results of our competitors but I think that we have performed quite well in April. But mainly, on the euro side and not in the fund units business. And regarding SMEs, the growth in the production of loans is driven quite 50-50 between short-term loans and medium-term loans. We have also good results in leasing, mainly a realistic leasing, but also as expected, short lease leasing in asset leasing. So we have a strong performance in terms of loans. I had – to hand that probably we have performed better than our competitors because just after the Kerviel crisis we assumed it was very important to say that we were there, to lend money to our consumers and so it's what we have done in February and March.
And is there some – can you specify, is there is some specific sectors on which you are pretty active or it's a wide – over the French industry?
No. It's split as the split between the different areas of industry that you have probably – it's a different slide. We don't notice anything special, this quarter.
Okay.

Maxence I think it is in line with what you can also see in the previous quarter and you have the details between operating loans and investment loans on the slide 13 and you can see that the growth is of the same magnitude 15.5% for operating loans and 14.7% investment loans for the business customers.
Okay. Thanks.
Next question.
We now have a question from Guillaume Tiberghien, Credit Suisse. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon, I just want to clarify the revenues of corporate and investment banking going into the second quarter. And I understand that you're basically saying that the 740 million of CDOs gain has reversed during the quarter. So does that mean that it's actually negative 740 in Q2? And also should we expect that the fair value adjustment on your own debt will also to a large extent have reversed in the quarter. So basically you could have a negative 1.2 billion in which case obviously, there would be a loss in SocGen CIB so I just wanted to clarify that. And also I listened to your comments on the cost in CIB, but I am not quite sure what we should basically expect in terms of sort of maybe not Q2, but medium term cost income in the corporate investment banking, because it does seem that the cost has sequentially been a bit too strong. So if you could just elaborate again on the cost that will be great? Thanks.

Guillaume, good afternoon. So I would take the first question and hand over to Jean-Pierre for the second one. On the first one, yes, the 743 million positive that we had in the first quarter has almost entirely melt down in April. So definitely your interpretation is correct, this means that we have the bulk of the same figure income of minus . Regarding the spread on SG signature, you can assume that the spread on SG signature are less volatile and assume there and they widen also a little bit less in the previous quarter. So we should not expect let's say the same type of full, let's say, reversal in the second quarter. And as we mentioned because it is very important that a fair value adjustment on the signature of Société Générale has no impact on the Tier 1. So the positive items that we booked in the fourth quarter for a bit more than €200 million and the items that we booked in the first quarter did not fall into in to the Tier 1 capital ratio of the group. I now hand over to Jean-Pierre for the cost income of SG CIB on the medium term.

Yeah, Guillaume, basically on the cost income we stick to our forecast, which and that's far as our cost income targets are for 2009. So you are right to say that for the first quarter we had a decrease of 4% of our cost where basically the base effect if I may say or the carry over effect from the increase of staff we had last year, increased our cost of staff, which was slightly more than offset by the decrease of bonuses because we had lower performance. But net-net our staff head count we had a very low turnover actually in Q1, which was very, very small and actually a tenth of what we had last year, so a very stable head count. But we have basically increased our head count between Q4 and Q1 by 0.9%. So relatively stable head count, but between Q1 '07 and Q1 '08 basically the increase was higher was around 12%. So the staff increase of 12% clearly translates in cost income, which is partially compensated by the bonus side.

Just to follow up, did you have to give any guaranteed bonus for people not to leave in order to protect the firm size? And secondly sorry I forgot the third question a very small one, on domestic retail did you confirm the revenue growth guidance for the full year of roughly nominal GDP thanks?

On guaranteed bonus side it's done through charismatic leadership, Guillaume so we have to give no more than last year in terms of guaranteed bonuses. So we are always very careful and we manage our guaranteed bonus outflow as small single digit components of our total bonus envelope. And on the retail side?

Yeah regarding the guidance I mentioned during the presentation that we do expect let's say revenues in French networks to grow at lower levels than last year and mainly on the back, let's say of the two items I did mention which already influenced, let's say the first quarter results on one side, uncertainty regarding the financial condition evolution in difficult market environment and also growing aversion for the risk by the retail customers. And on the other side, you know that we have only part of the impact of the 50 bps increase in the regulated deposit in the net interest margins this quarter. We will have the full impact in Q2, Q3 and Q4 and it is very likely looking at inflation level that we have seen over the last months in France, that there could be an additional 25 bps increase of the original rate on the first of August. And I remind you that 25 bps increase, for let's say five months for the original and four months for our passbook, is let's say discounting half a point on the growth of the revenues. So that's why we did not confirm the nominal GDP, which remains nevertheless our target for the medium term.
Thank you very much, very clear.
The next question is from Mr. Kimon Kalamboussis, Citigroup. Sir, please go ahead.

Yeah, hi, this is Kimon Kalamboussis from Citi. A question on life insurance first, please. You mentioned switches in euro products, in guaranteed product sorry, euro products, so would you know what the impact on capital would be if the current trends continue, please? Second question on CIB, is it worth sort of maintaining your target to reach €9 billion of revenues by 2010, if the current environment remains as it is, please? Thanks.

Kimon, good afternoon. Regarding your question on the life insurance. Well, you know that, well the capital charge burden in terms of capital is 4% of the mathematical provisions for the life insurance in euros and only 1% for the unit linked. Regarding our calculation in terms of capital allocation so this is booked in financial strategies and for the time being we are allocating at a 75% of the solvency margin requirements of the life insurance business, so the change in the -- will marginally, potentially increase the capital burden, but we believe, it does not change let's say the underlying profitability that we would have in this activity. I'll now pass to Jean-Pierre.

Yeah on the 2010 target. To answer your question clearly the current environment remains the same and if every month between now and 2010 is the same as March 2008 you know we do not maintain our €9 billion target, but we feel that the environment will normalize after a while and we are – as we said during our capital increase workshop a prospect in terms of growth for the economy on the worldwide basis of returning back to trend in the course of 2009 and being in quite a decent and quite a thriving environment by 2010. So when you look at the underlying dynamic of our business, we feel that the client side has been on the CIB side quite resilient in the first quarter and if I may say – I don't think our client business on the CIB side has been impacted on a consolidated basis by the fraud as some certain we had on some activities have been more than compensated by a very strong performance, namely on the flow product side. So the impact on the first quarter has much more been down to the environment rather than the fraud effect.

On the client side, we had underlying strength on the client side in the flow business on a consolidated basis in our flow business between the fixed income and the equity derivative side has reached record levels this quarter, which shows that the growth dynamic is there. We've seen on the structured product side that we said our projection in the GGS side and the equity derivative side was stable versus Q4. We feel that the environment and the equity market turning the growth there on the structured product will remain. And on the trading activity, we feel that in more normalized environment we have all the resources and ability to basically benefit from an improved market environment. So net-net, I speak firmly to the €9 billion of revenues by 2010, but within an economic assumption and an environment which is not the environment of the first quarter.

And perhaps to follow on that, I guess, what is very important is that as Jean-Pierre mentioned, that retention was high, let's say there was no deposit in quarter in the beginning of April, which is a very strong sign, and also the performance of the customer base, let's say the confidence of the customer base have been also very strong in the first quarter.
Thank you.
The next question is from Mr. Philip Richards, Execution. Sir, please go ahead.

Yeah, hi. It's Phil Richards with Execution. I've got two questions please. The first one is on slide 26, on the 11.2 billion of money market funds now held by the group. Can you just give us an indication on what's going to happen to the assets going forward? Do you expect to sell them down, and if so, could there be any losses on those assets? And secondly, is on slide 37, on the 417 million of basis risk. Please just give us some indication there of the breakdown between the RMBS and the CMBS asset classes, and also what we've seen so far in the second quarter of 2008, do you expect a further basis risk loss?

I will start with your question regarding the €11.2 billion of assets held by SG CIB on one side and Corporate Center on the other side. Regarding the 7.4 billion that are held by SG CIB they are booked in the trading portfolio of SG CIB. So, not let's say mentioning what will be the decisions of, Jean-Pierre will perhaps comment on that, so it is trading so it will be mark-to-market on a regular basis. Regarding the 3.8 billion that we have in the Corporate Center, these assets are classified under IFRS and healthy maturity, and so we believe that on these assets we have reviewed let's say the credit quality of the underlying assets, they are good credit rating assets, so we are more let say for time being considering to hold that in our book. Jean-Pierre on the second point, on the question regarding the equity credit.

Yes. On the 7.4 billion of assets we own in our portfolio coming from the SGAM side, you have breakdown on the values annexed on page 64 basically where we give the breakdown between the various assets and the split in terms of rating. You can see that the assets are of good quality between single A and above. We have 83% of the asset there. We have almost 100% of the assets which are investment grade. And the breakdown which is mentioned here shows that we have a balance between various ABS underlying. We have around €945 million of CMBS, almost all our European CMBS, with a very small proportion of UK and Spanish CMBS. On the RMBS side, we have €1.682 billion of RMBS. We have no US RMBS within the portfolio. They are for a very large part, 1.4 billion coming from European RMBS, with UK representing €550 million, and Spain 415, and we have there as well a large part, which is actually, a very large part, which is single A and above.

On the other ABS, we have 570 million which are split between auto loan, consumer loan, leasing and others, a large part coming from Europe, almost the credit totality coming from Europe. We have 1 billion of CLO, 1.025 billion of CLO, 860 are made from European assets. It's mostly SMEs, CLO for 626 million. We have a small part coming from leverage loan and from investment grade CLO, from corporate CLO, for 140 million. We have 29 million of US CLOs coming from corporate investment grade corporate for a very large part. And we have 534 million of CDOs basically, which are comprised for a large part of single A and above. We have basically on the CDOs side a good split between the values region, and we have, it's mostly Europe and Asia, and literally no new US CLOs or assets coming from the US, only for €4 million. So the markdown on the portfolio on the EPS portfolio. So as we have as well 2.6 billion coming from banks, European banks, as well as corporate debt issue. The markdown on this portfolio for derivative side is 9% on average on nominal. And looking at the quality of the underlying, I think it's more mark-to-market impact, not any real credit impact that we could anticipate. I'm not saying that we are going to see the mark-to-market coming back in Q2, but I think in the medium term part of this mark-to-market should – part of the totality of this mark-to-market come back.

On your question about basically the existing credit derivative book, we gave and I commented about the breakdown of the portfolio. I think that the impact of the loss that we took in Q1 is coming from two things, it's the basis risk as I said that we have basically a cash position and we have as well some index position, which are mostly hedging our delta hedge basically. And so there is a basis risk, but better so, negative convexity of the portfolio. This portfolio in the way it is structured, when clients, sellers, protection on the underlying assets, if the spread is wide enough and be wide enough to levels which were quite high, it creates the margin negative convexity, and it's like gamma minus position in the traditional portfolio, but I am not going to go into detail about that, which mean that we have to have hedges, which, when the market is volatile, could incur some losses. And we had sharp tightening of the credit in April, which had some impact on our basically negative convexity.

Great. Thanks. If I could just follow up one other last question is on the corporate center. Obviously the numbers are quite lot weaker then we've seen them previously. I know some of that is down to unmet sales of equity assets. But can you just talk a bit further about that number and then the minus 123 million of gross operating income.

Well, in fact, the structure of the Corporate Center, looking at what we booked at the Corporate Center, the structurally that such type of corporate operating income as soon as we are not able realize, or not willing to realize, any capital gains. This is the run rate that you should take going forward.
Thanks so much.
We now have a question from Mr. Omar Fall, ABN AMRO. Sir, please go ahead. Mr. Fall?
Next question.
The next question is from Mr. Maimoon Tedi, MF Global. Sir, please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. I have two questions if I may. One is a follow-on a previous question about the exotic CDSs. If you say that you have a narrowing of the spread that means that you will see writebacks in the second quarter? And the other question is, on page 31, when you said that some impact mostly raised at the end of April for the equipped mark-to-market of credit derivative, I assume that you must have some writebacks on the other side in the assets as these hedges are working with the assets unless you still have some basis risk there. So I just would like to understand if we will see some writebacks on the losses that we have seen in the first quarter as the protection see some losses.

Well, on your second question, we have hedges for our credit portfolio, which – for our loans which are in the banking book. So basically, the loans are held to maturity and per se, they don't impact our top line or neither do they impact our first line. So, this asymmetric treatment basically coming from IS where we offer the loans in banking book. So, no impact on the P&L. And the CDS which are basically on a mark-to-market basis and from a regulatory point of view those offset – basically if you have a loan with the CDS which recovers exactly the loan there is a regulatory offset so basically there's a capital relief. But on an accounting point of view we have this asymmetry, which means that when the credit spreads widen up, the loans don't impact the P&L, but the CDS show a gain.

And as we said, our portfolio is made as of the end of March of around €50.6 billion of hedges. They do have the period one net sensitivity of €14.1 million per basis point evolution of the average index if you want and the other an average maturity which is 4.3 years at the end of March. So basically spreads widen up, you have P&L has been tightened up, you have loss and the sensitivity €14.2 million per basis point. So as price tightens up quite strongly in April that creates loss which basically spreads at the end of April being not very far from the beginning of January. There has been basically, almost a total writeback of this as it shows at the end of March. It's part of, I guess, volatility of the accounts basically.

If I may – Maimoon we should mention that this CDS portfolio has three aims. The first one is to cover the credit risk of some loans in the portfolio, sometimes. Second one is to manage the concentration of the portfolio. And the last one also is sometimes just to regulatory let's say arbitrage to use the consumption, in term...
Yeah.
...a specific situations, so it's not a trading position, it's just that we are actively managing the portfolio, and so this book is there to stay.

And we don't sell any credit protection within the portfolio; we are only by way of credit protection. That's very clear. On your other question about, are we going to see writeback in April because the spreads have tightened up on our structure of the credit portfolio. As I said, the basis risk actually depending on the asset size not been necessarily moving in our favor, and the negative complexity of the book meaning that there is potentially some negative impact, we have showed in page 37 I think that we started the amount with loan protection. So showed credit of €1.8 billion in the market type and so there should be some losses coming from that. Not to the extent of what we saw in the first quarter, there should be some losses coming from that.

Let me understand; I mean if the purpose is to hedge your portfolio, then you should be getting at some point, some writebacks from the protection; if you don't have any writebacks from the protection, what's the point of having the hedges, apart from the fact that you're trying to manage your capital, but the main reason is to protect your portfolio.

No, no, on the structured credit portfolio, we run a portfolio which is very similar in the way it is managed to a traditional upfront portfolio. I mean, the technology, the models are very different, but it's the same concept. Basically we buy or sell products from clients, it creates some exposure within our books that we hedge. And within the portfolio depending on where the credit spreads are, we could have sensitivity to our book in terms of the delta hedge or the first derivative or the gamma evolution, which is the evolution of the delta, which is the second derivative, which can be going one way or another.

With the widening of the spread within our portfolio at the end of March and things are dynamically managed and could change, we have a book with a negative convexity. So basically when we have a negative convexity, if the market goes up, we have to buy, and if the market goes down we have to sell. So, you see, you go against the market, and with the sharp volatility of the underlying asset, it could create some losses as it happens when you manage a negative convexity book that option traders call a gamma negative book basically. The point of the hedge is to make sure that the sensitivity of the book is a first derivative sensitivity and not a sensitivity of the full nominal as we have disclosed. We have underlying assets, if you sum up the various underlying assets, which are of roughly €19 billion of assets. So, if we were not hedged we will have a sensitivity of €19 billion of assets by hedging we have a sensitivity which is a theoretically around zero, by this hedging, but which depends on what the traders are doing with their position and they started the quarter being effectively long credit protection.

So am I to understand that your client business in derivatives is a lot more risky than what you've been telling us in the past. That, that in situation like this you wouldn't be incurring losses that are larger than some of the revenues you generate?

No it's not more dangerous than what we have been telling you in the past. I think that you have to look back, for instance at the chart that we put at the beginning of the presentation. If you go back to one of the first slides basically of the presentation on page five, you can see the evolution of the spread basically, which varies around during the first quarter. You had for almost each asset class a very sharp widening and then a very sharp tightening of the credit spread. So basically the volatility during the first quarter, if you look at the credit market has been something, which has been never seen before. So it – I wouldn't draw a parallel with an equity market where it's active.

And there take my words with caution, but active equity indexes over the quarter moved on 50% and back up, which I would call it a very volatile quarter. We have that on the credit spread as you can see. And when we have such a volatility on the underlying credit spread, some of the position can show some losses, because of their overall structure. And on the structured credit side, we have decided to disclose our position, because the management of the position under such a volatile scenario showed a loss which was due to the very high volatility of the market. We were well beyond the stress test valuation that one could envisage, particularly in the management of this portfolio. In a normal market environment the underlying volatility of the portfolio in terms of revenues should be much, much lower.
And then when I mentioned that in the €470 million that we have negative in the first quarter, two-thirds of that was losses, so it's technically one third is write down.
That's correct.
Okay. Thank you.
We now have a question from Mr. Cyril Meilland, Lehman Brothers. Sir, please go ahead.
Yeah. Hello, can you hear me?
Yes.

Yeah. Okay. Good afternoon. I have two small questions. The first one is regarding life insurance. Because I would like to understand a bit better the dynamics of the revenue growth of 12.8% given that you have inflows down almost 17% and assets under management growing by only 3.9%. So where is the revenue growth coming from, is it because you – I mean you reserved a bit better than you did in the first quarter of last year or can you shed some light on this? And the second question is regarding the spreads in – not the margins, but the spreads in retail banking in France. Do you see any improvement in certain markets or would you say that competition is either fiercer or more equal to what it was in 2007?

So regarding the spreads within the French retail banking business, what we can say is that what we have seen this quarter is overall let's say a widening, but in certain category of loans, we have seen the spreads better let's say in terms of mortgage loans compared to last year, and also better mortgage investment funds and business loans.
It's very clear in terms of mortgage, it's also clear in terms of SME loans, but we are putting in those increases which are very low, specifically in mortgage last year.

Regarding your question on the life insurance, I propose perhaps to discuss that with investor relations team will provide you more detail on the evolution of the net inflows on one side, the evolution of mathematical provision. You know that there is always the technical results – which – in the financial results which are two elements important in assessing the performance of life insurance division.
Yeah, absolutely okay. Thank you.
We now have a question from Mr. Alberto Segafredo, Merrill Lynch

Hello. Good morning everybody. The first question regards the positive NBI uplift you booked in both Q4 and Q1 from the mark-to-market of your liabilities and treasury shares. Can you please list the two different components of the uplift? The second one is on the fiscal treatment of the potential write backs in Q2 and Q3. And the third quick question is again on the French retail banking outlook, I wanted to – usually Q1 is a quarter where you face a nice seasonality in the fee income side. I wanted to have your idea on what the outlook looks like for Q2 and Q3. And then the last question is on the rights issue of Crédit Agricole. I wanted to understand if you have been asked to underwrite their capital increase? Thank you.

So regarding your first question on the split between mark-to-market on our own debt revaluation of our net and owned shares, in the fourth quarter owned shares had a plus €6 million impact and fair value on sustaining our own debt was plus 242. And in the first quarter owned shares were nil, and as I mentioned a change in fair value of AD was 523.

On Crédit Agricole I think we will not comment on that. Your second question was linked to the fiscal treatment of potential writebacks, I would say they are – let's say writebacks are treated let's say in line with the tax position of the group overall, so it depends on where we also book this writeback whether it is in the U.S., London, Paris whatever. So we think into of the location. And lastly regarding the – your question regarding the perhaps quarterly perspective of the French network let say, that was a relatively mute on the full year, we will not comment...
Okay. Thank you very much.
The next question is from Jaap Meijer, Dresdner. Sir, please go ahead.

Hello, this is Jaap Meijer from Dresdner. Looking at your tier 1, this is pretty strong and you tier could – sorry, tier 1 is not at home, but your core tier 1 is very high. So, do you have any plans to launch tier 1 securities considering the hybrid is only 14%? And in your core capital of 6.8%, are there any non-common equity elements included in this one? And the other one is that, you reported an EPS of €2.06 and the small net-off positive one-offs, do you think that about this could be a good run-rate not withstanding potential losses in the Q2 where you alluded to previously? And pretty helpful the exposures to the ABS through creditors this related to the delta hedge and also helpful on Crédit Agricole Asset Management assets that have been to sold to CIB. But what kind of other investments do you have in ABS besides the subprime RMBS that we know of – so they should be reported under let's say AFS investments or under loans, that will be quite helpful? Thanks.

Okay. I will let Jean-Pierre answer to the third question. Regarding let's say your question regarding the core tier 1, so to that 6.8% and you made the right calculation we are currently 14% of the hybrid capital, let's say in our total tier 1 ratio. I will get the point yes, we know that the maximum that we can have under French regulation is 25%. So we have no comments to make further than that. Regarding your question on the 2.06 euro per share quarterly EPS, let's say this is not the policy of the group to make any guidance on run-rate or whatever. So I'll disappoint you but I will not comment on that. And on the last questions I will pass quickly to Jean-Pierre but we have already an extensive disclosure.

We clearly will give in our full disclosure in offering the recommendation of the financial stability form in our – for Q2. But clearly looking at the disclosure gave for the exotic derivatives book the position we have – in our ABS portfolio coming from the asset management side and we said that we had a small U.S. RMBS portfolio which was partially hedged and I think the nominal is on 500 million euro gross, which is hedged and the net sensitivity is around 40 million euro from memories.

We have covered a very large part of our ABS portfolio. From memories because I've not being going for that into detail, we might have 2 or 3 billion more additional ABS, which are split between various geographies, not in the U.S. but in Europe and in Asia. But you have here in all – the very large majority and between the exotic derivatives book, the RMBS book and the ABS of both from Scambia almost the credit totality of our ABS exposure.
So, you have nothing besides the 3 billion you talked about, let say in AFS investments, perhaps in insurance or in the bank or let's say under loan and advances, I guess?
On the CIB side we disclose everything approves on the insurance side; it was in the book of insurance, it's another story and I'll let Didier comment.
On the life insurance I'd say it is a third party investments or let's say we have an asset allocation which could invest in such underlyings but let's say this is done under very strict rules.

But no disclosure on that compared other bank assurers we've seen a lot more disclosures with split ups in all the categories; rating classes, insurers, credit enhancements whatsoever. And so you have improved your disclosure again with Q1, but now if you going to have surprises again in Q2, you may have to disclose even more, so just it would be better to disclose everything in full I guess?

What I could just mention to you also that as you seen the press release other comprehensive income at the end of March excluding revaluation reserves result were positive for €500 million as you can see also. But contrary to some of our peers which perhaps have disclosed little bit more we have still a positive OCI at the end of March.
Fair point. All right. Thanks.
We have the last question from Mr. John Raymond, Credit Suisse. Sir, please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Could you just explain please, the difference between the presentation of CDO exposure on slide 35 compared with slide 63 in the supplement. On slide 35, the growth exposure at the end of '07 of 4.9 and then write-downs of 1.6 which we've seen in the P&L leaving a net of 3.3 if you add it up. But then on slide 63 it says the gross nominal is 5.9 write-downs of three and a net of 2.9?

Yes. Well, on the page 35, we have shown basically the breakdown of our unhedged portfolio and where we have basically the subordination basically as well for our portfolio. So when you look at these CDOs there is basically the underlying components of the CDOs are made of various assets, so that's what we call on page 63, the gross nominal basically. And we have – we take all the assets, so the gross nominal and we have certain number of write-down depending on the category of assets, and you can see for instance that for the '06 and '07 vintages on the subprime side, we have written down our asset by 92%, 92% which is quite severe, write-down much more severe, that's what we have on the ABX.

And so, basically the write-down of 3 billion, it does not mean that we have 3 billion impact on our P&L, because we are protected on this asset by the subordination of our tranches, which are AAA. So ahead of us we have subordination, which is basically stocking from what we call the attachment point. So, as you can see on page 35, we have on portfolio one, a subordination of 28%, on portfolio two 15% and on portfolio three 35%. So, basically depending on the CDO with the write-down of the underlying asset, we started having losses when basically the write-down of asset goes beyond the subordination, so beyond the attachment point. And as the write-down recorded are basically for us write-down above the subordination while for the CDOs they are write-down on the overall total assets of the CDO. I hope I am clear in this explanation.
Yes, I think that's good. Thank you very much.
We have eventually one last question from Mr. Antonio Guglielmi, Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Yeah, good afternoon. Just one question on your Basel II disclosure. I was just wondering if you could tell us what is this 32 basis point negative capital deduction you are having, maybe some minority stakes or if you could give us more color please?

Yes, there is four components let's say in this deduction. The most important one and say that deduction of the stake of more than 10% that we do have in either non-consolidated or equity accounted banks. And for example, I think it will be the case for our French peers, we have a stake in Crédit Logement which is a mutual fund guarantee company in France, which is guaranteeing mortgages.
